title: Make the Keccak feature stable
body: Make the Keccak feature stable, remove the prove_zkr functionality.

title: rzup: Add publish command to upload to S3
body:
This PR adds two new commands to the `rzup` CLI.
- `publish upload` uploads a `.tar.xz` file to S3 under `rzup/components/<component>/sha265` and updates the `rzup/components/<component>/distribution_manifest.json` to mention the artifact
- `publish set-latest` which updates the `latest_version` field fo the `distribution_manifest.json`

`publish` help text
```
Publish a component on S3

Usage: rzup publish [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
  upload
  set-latest
  help        Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -v, --verbose  Enable verbose output
  -q, --quiet    Suppress output
  -h, --help     Print help

Discussion:
    Publishes a component to S3 at a particular version, or updates the current latest version.

    Requires that AWS credentials be available in the environment.

    Each version of a component is either tagged with a target, or is target agnostic. A particular
    version can only have one target-agnostic artifact, or many target specific artifacts, but each
    target may only have one artifact each.
```
`publish upload` help text
```
Usage: rzup publish upload [OPTIONS] <--target-agnostic|--target-triple <TARGET_TRIPLE>> <NAME> <VERSION> <PAYLOAD>

Arguments:
  <NAME>     Name of component to publish (e.g. rust) [possible values: cargo-risczero, cpp, gdb, r0vm, rust, risc0-groth16, self]
  <VERSION>  Version of the component to publish (e.g. 1.0.0)
  <PAYLOAD>  The path to the archive

Options:
      --target-agnostic                Is the component the same for all targets
      --target-triple <TARGET_TRIPLE>  The target triple of the component
      --force                          If the component at the given target / version already exists, replace it
  -v, --verbose                        Enable verbose output
  -q, --quiet                          Suppress output
  -h, --help                           Print help
```

`publish set-latest` help text
```
Usage: rzup publish set-latest [OPTIONS] <NAME> <VERSION>

Arguments:
  <NAME>     Name of component to update the latest version of (e.g. rust) [possible values: cargo-risczero, cpp, gdb, r0vm, rust, risc0-groth16, self]
  <VERSION>  Version to set (e.g. 1.0.0)

Options:
  -v, --verbose  Enable verbose output
  -q, --quiet    Suppress output
  -h, --help     Print help
```

title: release-2.3.1: Backports and version bump
Add support for 5090 to bento
body: tested on runpod and vast ai. thanks @sashaaldrick for helping test this out!

title: Add s3 region to Bento
body: Bento works with minio, but fails when using S3 in any other region besides us-west-2. This allows the region to be set.

title: Don't check RISC0_DEV_MODE env-var in guest
body:
Checking this environment variable was a needless mistake in the guest because we ignore the result anyway. This caused guests doing verification to require the sys-getenv feature, which is not what we want.

In addition to fixing the check I improve the test coverage of verifying receipts in the guest:
- Run our verify_guest example as a test (nothing seemed to be running it before)
- Remove `sys-getenv` feature from guest program (not requiring this is a goal)
- Add dev-mode feature/test for verify_guest (allowing this to work is another goal)

title: rzup: Implement installation of risc0-groth16 component
body:
This implements downloading and installing the new `risc0-groth16` component.

### The `risc0-groth16` component

This new component uses S3 to store its metadata and tar.xz files. This is the first component to do this, and a new S3 distribution has been added to support this. If this works out well we can transition existing components to S3 and not have to deal with downloading from GitHub anymore.

The risc0-groth16 component is implemented as "target agnostic" meaning the same bits are used on all platforms. The code for a target specific S3 component has been added but nothing is using it yet.

When this component is selected as default, no symlinks are created, only the `rzup` metadata is changed. Unclear that this default version for this component will be used for anything, if not it is fine.

I uploaded to S3 a dummy tar.xz for now under the version 1.0.0-beta1. We can edit the bucket to add the real files.

### S3 backed `rzup` components

The S3 distribution stores a `distribution_manifest.json` per component that contains a list of releases keyed by version and shasums for the artifacts. The artifacts are intended to be stored as objects at a "sha256" prefix keyed off of their base64-encoded sha256 sum. This should allow for releases to be obtained by the client atomically. Also it should allow for verification of the artifacts contents later in the client by verifying the sha256 sum.

I wish to add in a later PR a new `publish` subcommand to `rzup` which will upload artifacts to S3 and update the manifest accordingly. We can hopefully use this in our release GitHub action to store future releases on S3 automatically.

title: docs: delete ∑ sign in versioned docs
Add a way to programmatically enable dev-mode.
body:
This PR adds a way to programmatically enable dev-mode. It does this with the following changes

- Add new `with_dev_mode` builder function to `ProverOpts` and `VerifierContext`
    - controls new `dev_mode` state in respective structs
- New `dev_mode` (private) state in `ProverOpts`
    - defaults to previous value determination about dev-mode (env-var + cfg flags)
    - allows the dev-mode prover to be selected
    - forwards on to `dev_mode` state in `VerifierContext`
- New `dev_mode` (private) state in `VerifierContext`
    - defaults to previous value determination about dev-mode (env-var + cfg flags)
    - allows fake receipts to verify successfully
- New `dev_mode` field in proto-buf `ProverOpts` for client/server
    - Allows `dev_mode` selection to flow into the `r0vm` server
- `risc0_zkvm::is_dev_mode` deprecated in favor of new `ProverOpts::dev_mode` and `VerifierContext::dev_mode`
    - Programatic enabling now means there is no global way to know if dev-mode is enabled
- `FakeRecipt::verifty_integrity` is deprecated and now always errors
    - New `FakeReceipt::verify_integrity_with_context` must be used so it can read the dev-mode state

title: Update docs for 2.2
Update versions and semver baselines for 2.2.0 release
Stabilize bigint2 feature
body:
This moves the stuff marked as "unstable" in `risc0-bigint2` to be stable.
It also makes bigint2 support no longer require "unstable" inside `risc0-zkvm` and `risc0-build`

This makes all this code now participate in SemVer checks, which I think is good so as to prevent downstream compilation issues.

It does not remove the "unstable" feature from `risc0-bigint2`, as this would break anybody depending on that feature (like all the precompiles).

I find it rather unfortunate that all the precompiles require the "unstable" feature, it means in the future if we would want to add new things marked as "unstable" in `risc0-bigint2`, they would be enabled by all existing precompiles. I think newer releases of the precompiles should probably aim to forward the "unstable" feature flag from their users on to `risc0-bigint2` so the user can decide if they want unstable features or not themselves.

ZKVM-1413: Split out preflight from prove_segment. Run them in parallel in the worker.
body:
Splits up prove-segment into a preflight a prove_core. Runs preflight and prove_core at the same time in the actor worker.

Running preflight and proving at the same time creates a big speed up, bringing 5090 prove times for po2=20 down from 800ms to 400ms.

Things to consider
- the naming of the new API changes: `PreflightResults` `preflight` and `prove_segment_core`
- should new API changes be marked "unstable"?
- changes to the `scope!`s
- adjustment to the GPU locking
- changes to dev-mode to support new API
- actor timing update to split preflight and prove times

I will need to merge https://github.com/risc0/risc0/pull/3191 with this one. I'm hoping to merge it on top of this probably because I think it will be easier that way, since I have to probably redo the tcp metric stuff.

title: Backport slated changes and bump versions for 2.1
ZKVM-1400: Executor Bigint Smallvec Spillage
body: In the executor where bigints are handled, when loading, a Smallvec is allocated to read limbs into. Currently the inlined smallvec value is optimized for 8 u32 limbs. Although this code isn't related to BLS, BLS is used often by many people in the ZKVM and limbs sizes (at least in blst are 12 u32s), so through some profiling, I observed that we are constantly spilling over and heap allocating here anyways.

This does it by inlining functions, and vectorizing BytePoly operations.

My own benchmark which does 10 zeth segment preflights improves from ~17s to ~14s

title: ZKVM-1379: Add gdb support
body:
This adds a way to run the zkvm executor with a gdb server. This allows users to attach gdb to the executor and set breakpoints and do backtraces. This is enabled by passing `--with-debugger` to `r0vm` or calling `run_with_debugger` on `ExecutorImpl`.

The riscv32im gdb must be used and I added code to rzup to distribute it.

In order to create a portable version of gdb which works on multiple releases of Ubuntu (and likely other distros) I had to disable its Python support. This is a bit of a shame since I think the official Rust gdb plugins are written in Python.

I compiled gdb using our existing riscv gnu tools repository. I added a PR which updates the README to include instructions for building yourself.  https://github.com/risc0/toolchain/pull/3
I added the compiled binaries to the current release for the toolchain repo and this is where rzup downloads it from.

This is just an initial version, there are still many more features you might imagine it having.

- Force a bunch of hot functions around doing memory IO to be inlined
- Remove usage of trait object to allow more inlining
- Optimize bigint IO functions w.r.t heap allocations and copies
- Remove extra hashing of memory pages

The correct path is 'methods/guest/src/main.rs', which contains the password policy implementation (lines 12-25), PBKDF2 password hashing (lines 46-50), and password validation logic (lines 53-59). The file contains the core zkVM guest code that validates passwords against security requirements and generates secure password hashes

On my coreweave machine this took zeth execute down from 21s to 17s.

title: ZKVM-1369: Add `c-kzg` to list of precompiles
fix(risc0-build): canonicalize manifest dir
body:
## Description

I have a project that has guest methods located in the parent directory. e.g. 
```toml
[package.metadata.risc0]
methods = ["../../programs/risc0"]
```

Calling `risc0_build::embed_methods()` in `build.rs` results in
```
 ERROR: No package found in "<PATH>/../../programs/risc0"
```
because vanilla `Path` comparison here
https://github.com/risc0/risc0/blob/3df2b55e611bbd7c65303bc7ef35be69f5a93b4d/risc0/build/src/lib.rs#L258
only normalizes `.` occurrences.

title: ZKVM-1360: Drop legacy code and bump versions
ZKVM-1359: Remove extra copies from extract_zkr
body:
There are extra copies going on here when we realloc the `Vec` inside `read_to_end` and when we call `Vec::from`.

The larger the zkr the more of an issue this is. The zip format should have the size of the entry in it, so we can do better.

Additionally the cast from `[u8]` -> `[u32]` is one of higher alignment and kinda questionable. bytemuck will crash if the alignment is not high enough and likely or allocation aligns all allocations at > 4, but if we use a different memory allocator in the future this might not be true.

This was just something small I noticed when reading the recent recursion witgen GPU patch.

title: ZKVM-1345: Load word-aligned regions by words, not bytes
body: The base addr and size parameters of a `load_region` call are very often word-aligned, so we can load more efficiently word-wise than with a byte-by-byte loop. This improves performance on some bigint-heavy workloads: datasheet exec time for `zeth_shapella_50` goes from 757ms to 413ms, with smaller improvements seen on the other segments.

body: Updated the cd command to use the correct path to the hello-world example.

title: ZKVM-1342: Fix an issue with sys_read where it would read past the end of the
body:
supplied buffer, or fail in other ways.

The branch that had the issue was in the v2 kernel and only taken when the read is greater than 1024. By beefing up the test to do larger reads we can see the bug trigger.

The sys_read syscall would pass arguments in registers a0-a4. The first 3 registers (a0, a1, a2) are common to all the ecall_read syscalls. These are `syscall_ptr`, `buf`, and 'len`. The last two arguments (a3, ar) are `fd` and `nwords`.

On v2, we implement ecall_read differently where it accepts `fd`, `buf`, `len` as the first three common arguments. We end up adapting the API in the v2 kernel. The kernel calls the host ecall_read from kernel code. We stash the `syscall_ptr` in `fd` (the new ecall_read's `fd` argument not to be confused with sys_read's `fd` argument) and `buf` and `len` in their respective arguments, these are passed via kernel registers.

In the host ecall_read handler we unpack and adapt these arguments (the kernel registers a1 and a2) before calling into the syscall_read code (which we know to do thanks to a0) passing the two needed values (`buf` and `len` directly through).

Once in the syscall code we read the two other arguments, the actual `fd` and `nbytes` from the user register directly.

The return values are also different and there is code to adapt that including another ecall_read call to ferry the result, but its not relevant to the issue.

This all works fine, until we deal with reads greater than 1024. The new ecall API has the limitation of only doing reads <= 1024. So if we do reads >= 1024 the v2 kernel has to break up the read into smaller reads. This happens in the Rust implemented part of the kernel, and this is only taken for sys_read, the other syscalls aren't able to deal with chunking at all.

When we do this chunking though, we forget about the other sys_read arguments, in particular the value stored in a4. This value also contains the length and needs to be updated. By not updating it, the sys_read call does unexpected stuff, including reading not enough or too much.

title: ZKVM-1336: Executor adds soft cycle limit for per-segment execution
body: The `max_cycles` termination behavior on `Executor::run` is now configurable: the existing behavior is a "hard limit", which errors out if the limit is reached, but one can also request a "soft limit", which simply stops the VM and returns. This allows `Segment::execute` to provide the recorded suspend cycle as the cycle limit, which prevents execution from continuing to the next segment, for which there are no IO records.

title: ZKVM-1334: Hard disable fake receipt verification in the zkVM
body: In https://github.com/risc0/risc0/pull/2415 we disabled environment variables by default in the guest, so without explicitly enabling `sys-getenv`, a fake receipt will never verify. This PR goes further by disabling the verification of fake receipt and preventing any option from turning it on, bolstering the misuse resistance of the `Receipt::verify` API in the guest.

title: ZKVM-1332: enable poseidon2 syscall
ZKVM-1331: Bump the MAX_INSN_CYCLES for po2 >= 15
body:
This should help us avoid the large bigint program splitting issue. If a bigint program uses more cycles than this threshold, we may end up overflowing the segment and the execution errors. This threshold was too low, we had bigint programs that use more cycles in practice. After doing some worst-case analysis on the bigint programs we have current I came up with this new threshold.

Here is what the `bigint2-analyze` program estimates for our existing blobs
```
risc0/zkos/v1compat/src/bigint_v1compat/mul_256.blob
total = 8430
risc0/zkos/v1compat/src/bigint_v1compat/modmul_256.blob
total = 10838
risc0/bigint2/src/ec/ec_add_384.blob
total = 12716
risc0/bigint2/src/ec/ec_add_256.blob
total = 12456
risc0/bigint2/src/ec/ec_double_256.blob
total = 11809
risc0/bigint2/src/ec/ec_double_384.blob
total = 12045
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modsub_256.blob
total = 10814
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg2_add_384.blob
total = 10986
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfieldadd_256.blob
total = 10898
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modsub_384.blob
total = 10862
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg2_add_256.blob
total = 10898
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modadd_256.blob
total = 10806
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg2_sub_384.blob
total = 11010
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modinv_256.blob
total = 10874
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modinv_384.blob
total = 10950
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modmul_4096.blob
total = 14435
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfieldsub_256.blob
total = 10890
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modadd_384.blob
total = 10850
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg2_sub_256.blob
total = 10914
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg4_mul_256.blob
total = 19275
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_xxone_mul_256.blob
total = 12212
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfieldmul_256.blob
total = 12756
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_deg2_mul_256.blob
total = 12756
risc0/bigint2/src/field/extfield_xxone_mul_384.blob
total = 12356
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modmul_256.blob
total = 10838
risc0/bigint2/src/field/modmul_384.blob
total = 10898
```

title: ZKVM-1328: Add xtask extract-elf subcommand
body:
This command simply extracts the user and kernel elfs from a risc0 binfmt file.

This has been useful to have so things like `objdump` /   `gdb` / `llvm-dwarf-dump` can be run on the user elf.

title: ZKVM-1327: Return an error if "sha-256" is used for the hashfn
body:
Update `ProverOpts::fast()` to use poseidon2 for the hashfn, otherwise it will be unusable.

We didn't properly implement "sha-256" support for segment proving in v2. Instead of ignoring the hashfn value, we should check that it is "poseidon2", the only hashfn that we currently support.

title: ZKVM-1326: Don't error in the profiler when it gets confused about the call stack
body:
Its a bug that the profiler is getting confused about the call stack, and as a result may be producing bad samples (although probably just call-stacks which are parented incorrectly)

Its better to not error and produce some kind of profile, even if its less-than-perfect in some ways.

title: ZKVM-1314: Run fmt-markdown action on docs
body:
When working on https://github.com/risc0/risc0/pull/3083, I realized that running `bun run fmt-markdown` in the `website` directory results in changes (e.g. removed trailing whitespace). It seems that the `lint` action is not cactching this kind of lack of formatting. One issue would appear to be that the `lint` action does not use the same plugins, but this does not actually fix this issue either.

This PR commits the results of `bun run fmt-markdown`. It fixes one issue that might result in missed linting in our docs. It does not address the issue of failing to check strict formatting.

title: correct groth16 path in gitattributes
ZKVM-1312: Add a program that tries to do worst-cost analysis on BigInt program
body: It tries to figure out the worst-case in terms of paging cycles.

title: ZKVM-1311: Split RSA precompile into multiple modmuls
body: Instead of running a single monolithic RSA precompile, split it into its constituent modmuls.

title: ZKVM-1310: semver-checks: Implement checking of crate dependency version requirements
body:
We had an issue where we ended up breaking the 1.2.X build of the risc0 crates when we published 1.4.X versions of crates as part of the 2.0.0 release. This was because the 1.4.X crates ended up depending on 2.0.X versions of crates (`risc0-core` and `risc0-zkp` at a minimum) which conflicted with dependencies in other 1.2.X crates. This caused cargo to include both versions. This can be okay, but in this case it causes issues where the types are incompatible (because there are two different versions of these crates).

This adds a check to semver-checks that sees if a crate has a workspace dependency version requirement increase in major version, and if it does, we require that crate to also bump its major version. In the above situation it should have forced the 1.4.X crates to bump their versions to 2.0.X.

title: ZKVM-1309: use semver::VersionReq for comparisons in rzup build
ZKVM-1308: Fix & run Clippy for risc0-bigint2
body:
This adds a run with `-F unstable` to the clippy CI job. It also adds the corresponding fixes to risc0-bigint2. This caught a number of overlooked issues that only affected `unstable` functionality.

This includes the commit from https://github.com/risc0/risc0/pull/3069, which is a change clippy would have caught.

title: ZKVM-1306: Restrict Docker Hub Login to Internal PRs Only
body:
- GitHub secrets are not usable from external PRs by design, so the `Login to Docker Hub` steps in the `main.yml` workflow fail for external PRs:
  - Example: https://github.com/risc0/risc0/actions/runs/14224739449/job/39861422302?pr=3042
- This change only triggers the login step for internal PRs

title: ZKVM-1305: Add contracts table for v2.0
body: Adds the updated section for the v2.0 deployment.

title: ZKVM-1304: Run prover on Mac OS / aarch64
ZKVM-1303: dev docs: update zkvm spec for v2
